description:
Course content is based on a family centered approach in which the needs of the family members during various phases of the childbearing process are considered. The student is provided with a theory base necessary for the care of women, families, and their newborns. This theory base is organized according to the concepts of the person or family, environment, health and nursing and their relation to each other during childbearing. Using the nursing process, nursing strategies are developed for maintaining family members individually, for promoting optimal physiological and psychological functioning, and enhancing strengths within the family members and within the family unit. 

Clinical experiences provide opportunities for application and integration of the theory base with parents and newborns. The student participates in clinical experiences in a variety of settings including acute care facilities, the community, and the Instructional Technology Center (ITC). The student will care for families with both simple and complex needs in all phases of the childbearing cycle. During this course, the student will assist in managing the care of families during the antepartum, intrapartum, postpartum, and neonatal periods.
name: NURSING OF THE CHILDBEARING FAMILY: THEORY/CLINICAL

section.name: NURSING OF THE CHILDBEARING FAMILY: THEORY/CLINICAL

values.comments:
Course content for Nursing Care of the Childbearing Family is based on a family centered approach in which the needs of the family members during various phases of the childbearing process are considered. The student is provided with a theory base necessary for the care of women, families, and their newborns. This theory base is organized according to the concepts of the person or family, environment, health and nursing and their relation to each other during childbearing. Using the nursing process, nursing strategies are developed for maintaining family members individually, for promoting optimal physiological and psychological functioning, and enhancing strengths within the family members and within the family unit. Clinical experiences provide opportunities for application and integration of the theory base with parents and newborns. The student participates in clinical experiences in a variety of settings including acute care facilities, the community, and the Instructional Technology Center (ITC). The student will care for families with both simple and complex needs in all phases of the childbearing cycle. During this course, the student will assist in managing the care of families during the antepartum, intrapartum, postpartum, and neonatal periods.

Students commented that this course was challenging but contained “valuable” knowledge. The course was often described as “disorganized”. One of the biggest criticisms was that the research paper was “too focused on APA format and not on content.” Also, the grading was fair for exams but not for the paper which frustrated the students. In terms of course lectures, students found them to be “great.” One student summed up the course as helping her grow “tremendously in terms of thinking ability.”

This course is co-taught by Professors Guidera and Stern. Students described Professor Stern as an efficient grader, reliable, and a “great instructor”. Professor Stern was “concerned about her students” which many felt was a very positive aspect of the course. Some students could not comment on Professor Stern as she did not lecture much.

As a required course for the nursing major, this class is not appropriate for non-nursing students. Many individuals criticized the course for its disorganization, unfair grading scheme, unnecessarily large amounts of required readings, and not enough credit given for the clinical portion. Overall, students felt the course was good but would benefit from fewer readings, no group presentations, and greater consistency in grading techniques.

section.name: NURSING OF THE CHILDBEARING FAMILY: THEORY/CLINICAL

values.comments:
Course content for Nursing Care of the Childbearing Family is based on a family centered approach in which the needs of the family members during various phases of the childbearing process are considered. The student is provided with a theory base necessary for the care of women, families, and their newborns. This theory base is organized according to the concepts of the person or family, environment, health and nursing and their relation to each other during childbearing. Using the nursing process, nursing strategies are developed for maintaining family members individually, for promoting optimal physiological and psychological functioning, and enhancing strengths within the family members and within the family unit. Clinical experiences provide opportunities for application and integration of the theory base with parents and newborns. The student participates in clinical experiences in a variety of settings including acute care facilities, the community, and the Instructional Technology Center (ITC). The student will care for families with both simple and complex needs in all phases of the childbearing cycle. During this course, the student will assist in managing the care of families during the antepartum, intrapartum, postpartum, and neonatal periods.

Students commented that this course was challenging but contained “valuable” knowledge. The course was often described as “disorganized”. One of the biggest criticisms was that the research paper was “too focused on APA format and not on content.” Also, the grading was fair for exams but not for the paper which frustrated the students. In terms of course lectures, students found them to be “great.” One student summed up the course as helping her grow “tremendously in terms of thinking ability.”

This course is co-taught by Professors Guidera and Stern. Students described Professor Guidera as “awesome”, “a little unorthodox”, but always “engaging.” Professor Guidera was “concerned about her students’ progress” which many felt was a very positive aspect of the course. Most students found Professor Guidera to be approachable but sometimes not responsive to emails.

As a required course for the nursing major, this class is not appropriate for non-nursing students. Many individuals criticized the course for its disorganization, unfair grading scheme, unnecessarily large amounts of required readings, and not enough credit given for the clinical portion. Overall, students felt the course was good but would benefit from fewer readings, no group presentations, and greater consistency in grading techniques.

Many individuals criticized the course for its disorganization, unfair grading scheme, unnecessarily large amounts of required readings, and not enough credit given for the clinical portion. Overall, students felt the course was good but would benefit from fewer readings, no group presentations, and greater consistency in grading techniques.

Course content is based on a family centered approach in which the needs of the family members during various phases of the childbearing process are considered. The student is provided with a theory base necessary for the care of women, families, and their newborns. This theory base is organized according to the concepts of the person or family, environment, health and nursing and their relation to each other during childbearing. Using the nursing process, nursing strategies are developed for maintaining family members individually, for promoting optimal physiological and psychological functioning, and enhancing strengths within the family members and within the family unit. Clinical experiences provide opportunities for application and integration of the theory base with parents and newborns. The student participates in clinical experiences in a variety of settings including acute care facilities, the community, and the Instructional Technology Center (ITC). The student will care for families with both simple and complex needs in all phases of the childbearing cycle. During this course, the student will assist in managing the care of families during the antepartum, intrapartum, postpartum, and neonatal periods.

Students found the laboratory portion to be a good way to practice skills and do hands-on learning. However, most students also commented that the information they received in the lab was “inconsistent”, “unclear” and “highly variable.” Many students did not appreciate the lengthy readings and the “time consuming” nature of the modules. Despite the “potentially great learning experience,” the students felt the lab was “frustrating” and “stressful.”

Mrs. Iorianni-Cimbak is “committed”, somewhat approachable, and “works hard to accommodate students.” Students, though, felt that Mrs. Iorianni-Cimbak’s email responses to students’ questions were not helpful and often demeaning. Many students commented on the supporting lab staff in addition to Mrs. Iorianni-Cimbak. Overall, the students recognized the staff’s commitment to teaching but felt there were too many inconsistencies in the information provided to the students.

Students expressed a desire to have more standardization in the clinical demonstrations, exams, and grading policies. The written tests were described as “unfair” and “poorly worded.” The students felt that the clinical demonstrations were unnecessarily stressful. In general, the class suggested that the lab portion be made a separate course since it requires a great deal of time, reading, and skills practice. At this time, the lab is a required, graded part of the NURS210 course and is not recommended for non-nursing majors.
